title: How to Make Use of Spoiling Dairy Products

methods.name: Using Milk Before it Goes Bad

steps.headline: Substitute milk for water in your oatmeal to make it creamier.
steps.description: To make 2 servings of oatmeal, mix 2 cups (470 ml) of oatmeal, 1 cup (90 g) of rolled oats, 1/8 tsp (0.75 g) of salt, and 1/2 tsp (1.3 g) of cinnamon in a saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil, stirring occasionally, then reduce the heat to low and simmer the oatmeal for 3-5 minutes before removing it from the heat. When the oatmeal is cooled, add your favorite sweetener and toppings like sliced fruit, berries, or jam.

steps.headline: Make your own yogurt for a healthy treat.
steps.description: Heat ⁄2 US gal (1.9 l) of milk in a Dutch oven until just before it boils. Let the milk cool until it's comfortable to touch, then take out 1 cup (240 ml) of the warm milk and mix it with 1 cup (0.24 l) of commercial yogurt with active cultures. Stir the whole mixture back together in the Dutch oven, then put it in your oven with the light on to set up for 4 hours or overnight. Once the milk is set, pour off any whey from the top, then transfer it to a container and keep it in the fridge for up to 2 weeks. The longer the yogurt sits, the thicker it will be, and the more tart the flavor will be. The commercial yogurt will act as a starter, introducing the live cultures that will turn the rest of the milk into yogurt.

steps.headline: Make a creamy soup base from milk roux.
steps.description: To make a milk roux, melt 1/2 cup (115 g) of butter in a saucepan, the mix in 6 tbsp (90 g) of flour to make a paste. Slowly stir in 2 cups (470 ml) of milk and 2 chicken boullion cubes for added flavor and cook over low heat until the mixture thickens. Once your roux is ready, add more milk and any ingredients you want to use in your soup, like steamed broccoli and cheddar cheese or roasted chicken and mixed vegetables.

steps.headline: Treat yourself to a cup of hot cocoa.
steps.description: For a delicious way to use your milk before it goes bad, whisk together 2 tbsp (14.6 g) of cocoa powder, 1-2 tbsp (12-24 g) of sugar, a pinch of salt, and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of milk in a small saucepan. Heat the mixture over medium-low until all the sugar and cocoa dissolve completely, then whisk in the remaining milk. Heat the milk over medium, stirring occasionally, until it's hot, then stir in ⁄4 teaspoon (1.2 ml) of vanilla and serve. If you have some on hand, don't forget to top your cocoa with marshmallows!

steps.headline: Make your own creamy white sauce to serve over pasta.
steps.description: Bring 2 cups (470 ml) of milk to a boil in a saucepan, along with 1 bay leaf and 2 cloves. Turn off the heat and let the flavors infuse for about 20 minutes. Then, melt 3 1/2 tbsp (50 g) of butter in a separate saucepan and whisk in 5 1/2 tbsp (50 g) of flour. Cook this mixture for 2 minutes, then strain the milk and gradually whisk it into the roux. Continue cooking the sauce for 5-10 minutes or until it thickens, then season it with salt and pepper to taste. A bechamel sauce is a simple white sauce that's delicious with chicken, fish, and pasta. However, you can dress up the sauce however you like! For instance, you could make a cheese sauce by tossing in some cheddar or parmesan cheese, or you could add spices like cayenne and paprika to make a Cajun-inspired sauce.

steps.headline: Freeze the milk if you want to use it later.
steps.description: Commercial milk cartons have indentations that allow the carton to expand as it freezes. That means even if you haven't opened the milk, you can pop the whole carton into your freezer, where it will keep for up to 6 months. When you're ready to use the milk, move it into the refrigerator and allow it to thaw for 1-2 days. Gently swirl the container before you use it in case the milk separated.

steps.headline: Do not use the milk if it has curdled.
steps.description: If your milk has been pasteurized and has a little bit of a sour taste or smell, it's likely fine to use in a recipe. However, if the milk has any lumps or curdles in it, you absolutely should not use it for anything that you plan to eat—it's spoiled and should be discarded. Bathing in curdled milk isn't dangerous, but the smell would probably make it unpleasant.

steps.headline: Use the soured milk as a tenderizing marinade for meats.
steps.description: Place the meat you'd like to marinate into a resealable plastic bag, then pour in enough milk to cover it completely. Squeeze out any extra air, then place the bag into the refrigerator. If you're marinating chicken, leave it in the fridge for about 2 hours. Marinate pork for 4 hours, and allow beef to tenderize for 24 hours.

steps.headline: Replace buttermilk with soured milk in your favorite recipes.
steps.description: Buttermilk is frequently used to give baked goods a delicious tangy touch. If your milk smells a little bad but you'd still like to use it up, search for your favorite cake, biscuit, or pancake recipe that calls for buttermilk, and use that milk instead. Buttermilk biscuits make a great side for any dish! Pancakes made with buttermilk are light, fluffy, with a rich flavor. Mix sour milk into your pizza dough to make it more flavorful than a standard recipe.

steps.headline: Try making homemade ricotta cheese for a fun afternoon project.
steps.description: Add 1 tsp (6 g) of kosher salt to 1  qt (0.95 l) of sour milk, then heat the milk over medium-high until it starts to steam. Add 3 US tbsp (44 ml) of lemon juice to the milk and let it sit for 5 minutes, during which time the milk will curdle. Then, place a piece of cheesecloth in a strainer over a bowl. Pour the cheese into the cheesecloth and let it strain until it's the consistency you're looking for. Allow the cheese to drain for 45-60 minutes to make a softer ricotta, or 1-2 hours if you'd prefer a thicker cheese. To make queso fresco, use white vinegar instead of lemon juice and double the salt. After you strain the curds, form them into a disc and press them with a weight until the cheese is ready.

steps.headline: Take a milk bath for a luxurious option.
steps.description: Milk is great for your skin, so if you have milk that's soured, try filling your tub with water, then pour in 1–2 cups (240–470 ml) of milk. Soak in the milk for 20-30 minutes or until the water cools, then enjoy the soft, glowing skin you get as a result! When it's diluted this much, milk that's slightly soured shouldn't have much of a smell.

steps.headline: Water your plants with sour milk to give them calcium.
steps.description: If you have spoiled milk on hand and you aren't sure what to do with it, try pouring it in the soil around your houseplants or in your garden! While it's not really practical to rely on milk as a long-term fertilizer for your plants, it can provide them with a little boost, and it saves you from having to toss it out. The milk may also help prevent powdery mildew from forming on your plants.

steps.headline: Wear goggles and gloves when you handle lye.
steps.description: Before you start making milk soap, it's important to know that you'll be working with lye. Lye can cause serious burns to your eyes and skin, so you should take safety precautions like working in a secure area where the lye won't be disturbed, and wearing safety gear like protective goggles and heavy-duty gloves. Always keep lye out of the reach of children. Tip: To ensure you get the exact measurements you need, use a digital scale to weigh out each item you're using to make the soap.

steps.headline: Freeze 10 fluid ounces (300 ml) of milk overnight.
steps.description: Since lye gets very hot, it's best to start with extremely cold milk. The best way to do this is to freeze the milk overnight. It will melt very quickly when you start adding the lye. Try pouring the milk into a resealable plastic bag to freeze it.

steps.headline: Place a stainless steel or glass bowl inside of a larger bowl of ice.
steps.description: The lye will heat as you mix it, which can scorch the milk if you're not careful. To help prevent this, set the bowl you'll use to mix the lye inside of a bowl that's full of ice. Then, place that bowl inside of your sink or in a secure spot on your countertop. If the ice melts during the soapmaking process, replace it.

steps.headline: Break the frozen milk into chunks and add it to the mixing bowl.
steps.description: Carefully chip the ice into large pieces with an ice pick, or bang the block of ice on the countertop firmly until it breaks up. Then, place the chipped milk into the stainless steel or glass mixing bowl you prepared earlier. If breaking up the ice doesn't work, you can let the milk thaw a little until it starts to get slushy—just make sure it stays very cold.

steps.headline: Stir 4.3 ounces (120 g) of lye very slowly into the milk.
steps.description: Add a little of the lye to the bowl, being very careful not to splash it onto yourself. Stir it in thoroughly, making sure the lye is fully dissolved before you add any more. Continue until you've dissolved all of the lye in the milk. Try using a potato masher to mix the lye into the milk, although a large spoon will work if you don't have one. It's normal for the milk to turn yellow, tan, or orange. However, if it turns dark brown, the lye has scorched the milk, and you'll need to start over.

steps.headline: Soften your coconut oil, then mix in olive and castor oil.
steps.description: Gently heat 8 oz (230 g) of coconut oil on your stovetop or in the microwave until it liquifies. Then, mix in 22 oz (620 g) of olive oil and 1 oz (28 g) of castor oil. Since you'll be adding the lye to this mixture, use a stainless steel or enamel-lined container. If you don't have one, use a heavy plastic bowl, but be aware that you may not be able to remove the odor of the lye from the plastic. Do not use any container that you intend to use again for food prep.

steps.headline: Drizzle the lye mixture into the oil and stir until it thickens.
steps.description: Use a whisk or large spoon to stir the oil constantly as you slowly pour in the lye and milk combination. After you've added all of the lye, keep stirring until the mixture is about the same consistency as a thick pudding. If you'd like, you can use an immersion blender to stir the mixture, but it's best to stir it by hand for the first 5 minutes. Once the soap thickens, you can add essential oils to make scented soap, if you'd like.

steps.headline: Pour the soap into silicone soap molds and let it sit for 24 hours.
steps.description: Once your soap is thick enough, pour it into a silicone mold, then let it rest for about a day to harden. Try not to disturb the mold, and avoid stirring the soap during this time, or it may not set properly.

steps.headline: Slice the soap into bars and cure it for 4-6 weeks.
steps.description: Turn the soap out of the silicone molds and use a sharp knife to carefully cut it into bars about 1–1 ⁄2 in (2.5–3.8 cm) thick. Then, place the slices on parchment paper and let them harden for up to 2 months. The soap will mellow during the curing process. If you use it too soon, it might be too harsh on your skin.

methods.name: Finding Uses for Other Dairy Products

steps.headline: Turn yogurt into a frozen treat before it goes bad.
steps.description: Yogurt has a tendency to last longer in the fridge than many other soft dairy products, so it may still be good for a while even after the expiration date. However, if you want to use it in a hurry, try mixing it into a smoothie or a delicious batch of homemade frozen yogurt. You can also use plain, unsweetened yogurt as a substitute for butter or sour cream in recipes.

steps.headline: Add sour cream to your favorite baked goods.
steps.description: Sour cream adds moisture and richness to cakes, muffins, cookies, and more. For instance, you might add about 1 cup (240 ml) of sour cream to your favorite cake recipe to make it nice and rich without affecting the liquid balance of the recipe. Sour cream is also delicious when added to vinaigrettes, tossed with pasta, or mixed into scrambled eggs.

steps.headline: Remove the exterior from hard cheese that's turned.
steps.description: Hard cheeses have the longest shelf life of any dairy product. In fact, even if mold develops on your cheese, it's typically only found on the outside. In that case, you can just use a sharp knife to completely cut away the surface of the cheese. Whatever's left inside should be just fine to use the way you normally would.
